questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with complaints of chest pain, hemoptysis, and severe dyspnea. CT scan showed vessel sign suggestive of pulmonary infarction. Which among the following is typically responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary infarction as suggested by CT is typically due to a small pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary infarction occurs when small thrombi lodge in the segmental and subsegmental vessels. These patients most often have pleuritic chest pain as the site where the thrombus lodges are near the innervation of pleural nerves.

Massive pulmonary emboli and saddle emboli that occlude the main pulmonary artery cause hypotension and shock as opposed to infarction. These are caused by larger-sized emboli that lodge more proximally in the pulmonary circulation.

Pulmonary embolism is classified based on the degree of reduction of pulmonary vascular blood flow and associated hemodynamic disturbances: 

  • Massive: Hypotension lasting for >15 minutes or BP maintained with inotropes.
  • Submassive: No hypotension, but features of cardiac injury present.
  • Non-massive: No hypotension or features of cardiac injury. 

CT findings associated with pulmonary infarction include a feeding vessel or vessel sign as shown below. It depicts a distinct vessel feeding directly to a lesion, usually of hematogenous origin. However, it is not specific for pulmonary infarction.

questions.text: A patient with a suspected pulmonary embolism underwent a chest X-ray. It showed an enlarged right descending pulmonary artery.  What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Enlarged right descending pulmonary artery on a chest X-ray in pulmonary embolism is called Palla’s sign.

The black pleura sign is seen in alveolar pulmonary microlithiasis. It refers to the shadow of the pleura between the extensive alveolar calcification and the adjacent rib cage.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Echocardiography in a patient with pulmonary embolism revealed akinesia of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion at the right ventricular apex. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The sign described is called McConnell’s sign.

It demonstrates right ventricular dysfunction as akinesia of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion at the right ventricular apex. It is the best-known indirect sign of pulmonary embolism on transthoracic echocardiography. 

Moses' (Bancroft's), Homan’s, and Lowenberg’s signs are seen in venous thrombosis. They're not specific to pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Signs related to venous thrombosis

Sign

sign 

 Clinical sign found in patients with deep vein thrombosis of the lower leg involving the posterior tibial veins. The sign is positive if pain is elicited when the calf muscle is compressed forwards against the tibia, but not when the calf muscle is compressed from side to side.

questions.text: Which of the following biomarker is least likely to be elevated in a patient with pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
NGAL (Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin) is a kidney injury marker and not a cardiac injury marker.

The following are biomarkers of cardiac injury in pulmonary embolism:

  • Plasma brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)
  • Heart-type fatty acid binding protein
  • Troponins.

Serum troponin and plasma heart-type fatty acid-binding protein levels increase because of right ventricular microinfarction. Myocardial stretch causes the release of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) or NT-proBNP.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions is likely to show increased D-dimer values?

1. Myocardial infarction

2. Pneumonia

3. Pregnancy

4. Sepsis
questions.solution:
All of the conditions mentioned above have raised D-dimer levels.

D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product.

Plasma D-dimer levels commonly rise in DVT and pulmonary embolism due to the breakdown of fibrin by plasmin. D-dimer is more sensitive to pulmonary embolism than DVT. The sensitivity of D-dimer levels in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is > 95% but it is is not specific for pulmonary embolism.

Normal D-dimer rules out pulmonary embolism in low and intermediate-risk patients. Patients with a high risk of PE should undergo a CT pulmonary angiogram to effectively rule out PE.

Conditions which have raised D-dimer levels include:

  • Myocardial infarction
  • Pneumonia
  • Sepsis
  • Cancer
  • Postoperative state
  • Pregnancy- second and third trimester

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset pain in the right leg. The pain is associated with swelling, redness, and tenderness. Which of the following is false regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Recurrence of this condition despite intensive anticoagulation is an indication for IVC filter
IVC filters can prevent recurrent PE in patients of right heart failure
IVC filters reduce the rate of recurrence of this condition
Pulmonary thromboendarterectomy is done in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). IVC filters increase the rate of recurrence of DVT (by providing a nidus for clot formation) even though they usually prevent pulmonary embolism (over the short term).

The two principal indications for insertion of an IVC filter are:

  1. Active bleeding (prevents the use of anticoagulation)
  2. Recurrent venous thrombosis despite intensive anticoagulation

Prevention of recurrent PE in patients with right heart failure who are not candidates for fibrinolysis and prophylaxis of extremely high-risk patients are some other indications for filter placement.

Patients impaired by dyspnea due to chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension should be considered for pulmonary thromboendarterectomy.

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CT pulmonary angiography should be performed as it is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).

Option A: Most patients with acute PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation-perfusion scan can be done. 

The images below demonstrate a pulmonary embolus (marked by arrows). The image of the gross specimen shows saddle thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis in his right limb. Which of the following parameters is a part of Well’s criteria that assess the clinical likelihood of pulmonary embolism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hemoptysis is a parameter in Well’s criteria used to assess the likelihood of pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: In a patient with a Well's score of 1.5, which of the following should be the initial investigation?
questions.solution:
A patient with Well's score of 1.5 has a low probability of pulmonary embolism. The initial investigation should be the measurement of D-dimer levels.

In a patient with a high probability of pulmonary embolism, the initial investigation is CT pulmonary angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for fibrinolytic therapy in a patient diagnosed with massive pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
For fibrinolysis (thrombolytic therapy) in massive pulmonary embolism, the only widely accepted indication is persistent hypotension or shock. It is defined as SBP <90mmHg or a decrease in SBP by ≥40 mmHg from baseline for >15 minutes.

Alteplase or recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), streptokinase, and urokinase are approved for the treatment of PE. tPA is the most commonly used fibrinolytic, but it is not superior to other agents.

Pulmonary embolism is classified based on the degree of reduction of pulmonary vascular blood flow and associated hemodynamic disturbances: 

  • Massive: Hypotension lasting for >15 minutes or BP maintained with inotropes.
  • Submassive: No hypotension, but features of cardiac injury present.
  • Non-massive: No hypotension or features of cardiac injury.

Contraindications for thrombolysis:

  • Haemorrhagic stroke
  • Ischemic stroke in the last 6 months
  • CNS tumours
  • Major surgery/trauma in the last 3 weeks
  • Active bleeding
  • Bleeding diathesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with SLE, secondary anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome develops pulmonary embolism. After admission, she is started on anticoagulants. For how long should the anticoagulation therapy be continued?
questions.solution:
Duration of anticoagulation for DVT and venous thromboembolism secondary to antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) is lifelong.

Duration of anticoagulation for DVT and venous thromboembolism:

Clinical Scenario Duration of Anticoagulation
DVT isolated to an upper extremity or calf that has been provoked by surgery, trauma, estrogen, or an indwelling central venous catheter or pacemaker 3 months
Provoked proximal leg DVT or PE 3 to 6 months
For patients with cancer and VTE

Prescribe LMW heparin

Continue anticoagulation indefinitely unless the patient is rendered cancer-free
Idiopathic unprovoked VTE Indefinite
Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome Indefinite

questions.text: Which of the following drug was recently approved by FDA for the extended prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism in hospitalized medically ill patients?
questions.solution:
Betrixaban is a new oral, once-daily factor Xa inhibitor approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for extended-duration prophylaxis of VTE in acute medically ill patients.

In patients with no obvious risk factors for VTE, early ambulation with or without mechanical methods (pneumatic compression stockings or venous foot pump) should be advised.

In patients with one risk factor for VTE with no risk of bleeding, LMWH is preferred. In presence of renal failure/cost issues, unfractionated heparin is used. In the case of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, fondaparinux is preferred.

In patients with multiple risk factors, increasing the dose of anticoagulants or using a mechanical device is advised. For patients with risk factors and a high risk of bleeding or contraindication for anticoagulation, mechanical methods are recommended.

choices.text: Compression of right iliac vein by right iliac artery
Compression of right iliac vein by left iliac artery
Compression of left iliac vein by right iliac artery
Compression of left iliac vein by left iliac artery

questions.solution:
May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is caused when the left iliac vein is compressed by the right iliac artery against the fifth lumbar vertebra. It is also called iliocaval venous compression syndrome, iliac vein compression syndrome, Cockett's syndrome, and venous spur.

Most patients have a partial obstruction and are asymptomatic. It can however progress to symptomatic extensive deep vein thrombosis (DVT). It is a cause of recurrent DVT affecting the left leg.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with a cardio-respiratory compromise. Chest X-ray shows a focal area of oligemia. The ECG of the patient is shown below. Choose the false statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Most common ECG abnormality is sinus tachycardia
Most preferred preliminary investigation is D-dimer

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. ECG shows the S1Q3T3 sign (i.e, an S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III) that is relatively specific but insensitive. The most common sign of pulmonary embolism is tachypnea.

Most common symptom of pulmonary embolism is dyspnea. Most common ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia.Most common preliminary investigation used is D-dimer.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman underwent bariatric surgery. On postoperative day 4, she developed pulmonary embolism as confirmed by a CT pulmonary angiography. Her blood pressure was 70/44 mmHg with poor urine output.  IV fluids were administered with dobutamine after which the blood pressure increased to 82/54 mmHg.  What is the most appropriate next step to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Surgical pulmonary embolectomy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. 

This patient is suffering from a massive pulmonary embolism. In such cases, thrombolytic therapy is given once diagnosis is made using CT pulmonary angiography or bedside ECHO.

But, since this patient underwent a large open abdominal operation (bariatric surgery), thrombolysis is contraindicated due to the increased risk of life-threatening bleeding. Therefore, surgical embolectomy must be done. The main pulmonary arteries are incised, and fresh clots are removed.

Contraindications for thrombolysis:

  • Haemorrhagic stroke
  • Ischemic stroke in the last 6 months
  • CNS tumours
  • Major surgery/trauma in the last 3 weeks
  • Active bleeding
  • Bleeding diathesis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old lady was admitted with unprovoked pulmonary embolism from left distal leg DVT. On admission, her coagulation studies were normal. She was started on unfractionated heparin with the first dose of warfarin on the same day.

After 48 hours of starting warfarin: INR = 3.5

Heparin was discontinued, and warfarin was continued at a reduced dose.

On day 4:

  • Extensive left leg proximal DVT progressed from the previous scan.
  • INR = 4.2

How will you manage her?

choices.text: Discontinue warfarin and start long term low molecular weight heparin
Send HIT tests and start argatroban or lepirudin

questions.solution:
This patient had suboptimal anticoagulation management. The best approach would be to reinstitute heparin and continue warfarin.

The patient had unprovoked PE from lower limb DVT. She was started on warfarin bridged with heparin initially.

Warfarin & parenteral anticoagulation need to be overlapped for at least 5 days, independent of the INR achieved during these 5 days in patients with acute venous thromboembolism.

Warfarin inhibits protein C, protein S (which is part of the fibrinolytic pathway) in addition to factors II, VII, IX, X. Protein C has a short half-life (4-6 hours) and thus decreases early. Since protein C is antithrombotic, decreased levels of protein C by warfarin renders the patient hypercoagulable during the first few days of treatment before factor II with a long half-life (36 hours) decreases and protects the patient from thrombosis.

Thus warfarin creates a prothrombotic state in the first 5 days putting the patient at risk of progression of thrombosis unless a parenteral anticoagulant is given overlapping warfarin for these days.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is admitted with unprovoked pulmonary embolism. On admission, her PT was 13.6 seconds (normal 9.6-13.4 seconds) and aPTT was 62 seconds (normal 28.2-34.6 seconds). She has no history of bleeding. Thrombophilia work up was done and she was found to have a strong lupus anticoagulant. How will you manage the patient’s initial anticoagulation?

choices.text: Start intravenous unfractionated  heparin with aPTT goal in the upper therapeutic range
Start intravenous unfractionated  heparin and monitor with anti Xa tests
Start warfarin without heparin bridge because aPTT is already in the therapeutic range
Start intravenous argatroban and monitor by aPTT

questions.solution:
This patient is most probably suffering from antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) as her lupus anticoagulant is strongly positive. In such patients, the initial anticoagulation is with unfractionated heparin and is monitored by anti-Xa tests.

Due to the presence of lupus anticoagulant, the lab measurement of aPTT will show erroneously prolonged aPTT. Therefore, even though there is an apparently prolonged aPTT, the patient is at increased risk of thrombosis and not bleeding, and hence patients with APS should be anticoagulated.

Anti Xa tests are not influenced by APS. So, the patient can be monitored for the adequacy of anticoagulation with UFH by monitoring anti-Xa.

Option A: The patient’s aPTT is already prolonged due to lupus anticoagulant, so we cannot monitor the patient with aPTT after starting unfractionated heparin.

Option C: Warfarin in the first few days of therapy, causes a decrease in Protein C & S levels, causing a prothrombotic state. Hence, a heparin bridge is necessary for APS which is already a pro-thrombotic state.

Option D: Argatroban is a direct thrombin inhibitor used in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia(HIT) to prevent thrombosis and also to increase platelet levels. Therapy is monitored with aPTT.

Note: Lupus anticoagulant may function as an inhibitor in vitro by binding to the reagent phospholipid and blocking the phospholipid-dependent reactions of the intrinsic pathway. The net effect is a prolongation of the aPTT.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score?
questions.solution:
The risk of developing pulmonary embolism in this patient is high (Option B) according to the three-tiered Well’s clinical risk assessment score. 

Calculation of Well's score:

  • Clinical signs of DVT = 3;  - swelling of legs, pain on palpation (Moses sign)
  • No alternative diagnosis = 3 
  • Heart rate is <100 BPM = 0; - 70 BPM
  • Surgery in previous 4 weeks = 1.5; - hip replacement surgery 1 week ago 
  • No previous pulmonary embolism = 0
  • No Hemoptysis = 0
  • No malignancy = 0; - no significant weight loss 

Total score = 7.5

Risk stratification:

  • High risk =  > 6.0
  • Moderate risk =  2.0 to 6.0
  • Low risk = <2.0 (in patients with low risk, to further confirm the risk - pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC) may be referred) 

Note: There is no other alternative diagnosis which is more likely in this condition, where there is a clear clinical presentation of a deep vein thrombosis, with the associated risk factors of a recent surgery and immobilization. Hence, 3 points can be added to the score.  

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5

Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm

  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
